chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Distinction between the Field and the Knower of the Field
sanskrit:
यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः |
क्षेत्रं क्षेत्री तथा कृत्स्नं प्रकाशयति भारत ||३३||
transliteration:
yathā prakāśayaty ekaḥ kṛtsnaṁ lokam imaṁ raviḥ |
kṣetraṁ kṣetrī tathā kṛtsnaṁ prakāśayati bhārata ||33||
translation: Just as the one sun illuminates this entire world, so does the Lord of the field (the Self) illuminate the entire field, O Bharata.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna provides a beautiful analogy to illustrate the relationship between the Self (kṣetrī, the knower of the field) and the body-mind complex (kṣetra, the field). Just as a single sun, though one, illuminates the entire world and makes all objects visible, similarly the one conscious Self illuminates and gives consciousness to the entire field of body, mind, senses, and experiences. The sun does not become the objects it illuminates, nor is it affected by them; likewise, the Self remains distinct from and untouched by the field it illuminates.

This analogy emphasizes the non-dual yet distinct nature of consciousness. The Self is the witness-consciousness that makes all experiences possible, yet remains transcendent to them. Just as without the sun's light nothing would be visible in the world, without the light of consciousness, no experience, thought, or perception would be possible. The verse underscores that while there are many bodies and minds (fields), the illuminating consciousness is fundamentally one, though it appears to be individualized in different beings.

This teaching is central to the Vedantic philosophy presented in Chapter 13. It helps the spiritual aspirant understand that their true nature is not the limited, changing field of body and mind, but the eternal, unchanging consciousness that illuminates all experience. This realization is the key to liberation, as it frees one from identification with the temporary and leads to recognition of one's true, immortal nature.
speaker: Krishna
